Three big changes come into force on the laws around driving on March 1 - and if you don't know about them yet, then you really should. 
These are the laws it's imperative you know about over the course of March - and, more importantly, how they are set to impact your day-to-day life. 
They will impact how you drive and how you care for your child. Read More 
Here is what you need to know: Using phone at the wheel 
Drivers caught using their phone while driving will receive SIX points on their licence from March. 
Watch: Changes to the law on using your mobile at the wheel Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share this video Watch Next 
The new, stricter rules are set to come into effect from March 1, 2017, and will see motorists slapped with £200 fines. 
The changes are set to have a significant impact on young drivers in particular, as they risk having their driving licence revoked following a first offence. 
Motorists will no longer be offered the opportunity to go on a driver awareness course. Child car seats 
The regulations around car booster seats have now changed. 
You can read our complete break down of the new car seat rules here , but to put it simply the new laws aim to improve kids' safety by stopping manufacturers introducing new backless booster seats for children who are smaller than a certain size. 
Watch: New rules to stop younger children using backless booster seats Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share this video Watch Next 
UK law states that children must use a child car seat until they’re 12 years old or 135cm (4ft 5in) tall, whichever comes first. 
But safety experts recommend you use a child car seat for all children under 150cm (4ft 11in). 
For children weighing more than 36kg (5st 10lb) but under 150cm (4ft 11in) it is advised to go by height. 
Remember it is the driver’s responsibility for children being in car seats while travelling. 
Under the new rules, backless booster seats will only be approved for use for children taller than 125cm and weighing more than 22kg. Read More New car tax rules that could cost you Using any 'internet device' at the wheel 
Under the new legislation the penalties for anyone caught using their phone - or any 'internet device' behind the wheel have been doubled. 
Others drive and text, and even 'live-stream' their driving on Snapchat or Instagram in a bid to to impress friends. 
With the changes taking place this week police have issued the following advice: Switch off before you drive off. Even if you’re using a hands-free phone you should avoid making or answering calls when driving. All phone calls distract drivers' attention from the road. Park safely before using your mobile phone. DO NOT park on the hard shoulder of the motorway. Don't call other people when they're driving. If you call someone and they tell you they are driving, ask them to call you back when they have parked up safely. Like us on Facebook
